title: Capacitor electron moving between charged plates

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Two oppositely charged parallel conducting plates each have area <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>A</mi></math> and are separated by a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. There is a hole in the center of each plate through which electrons can pass. Electrons emitted by an electron source enter the top plate with speed <math alttext="v sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and leave the bottom plate with speed <math alttext="v sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. The direction of the electric field <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi></math> in the region between the two plates points towards the top plate. Gravitational effects can be neglected. (a) Indicate whether the final speed <math alttext="v sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mstyle></math> is less than, equal to, or greater than the initial speed <math alttext="v sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. Justify your reasoning using physics principles.
